DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 3-146. - Required for sale or possession for sale.
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or possess for the purpose of sale any alcoholic beverage when such
person is not operating pursuant to a license to sell or possess for sale such alcoholic beverages, or to sell any
alcoholic beverage in violation of the terms of the license or of this article.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-147. - Separate application and license required for each location of sale; jointly held license for
concessions and similar arrangements.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
51/414
(a)
Each license under this article shall be limited to the operation of an establishment or enterprise for the sale of
alcoholic beverages at a specific location as set forth in the license. Separate applications must be made and
separate licenses must be obtained for each location at which an activity requiring a license is conducted.
Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer from catering or
supplying a private party or gathering being put on by a third party at a location other than that covered by the
license.
(b)
For a retail consumption dealer, if the sale of alcoholic beverages within an establishment or business at a
specific location is handled through a concession contract, the license for such location shall be obtained jointly
in the name of the entity which operates the business or establishment within which such concession is located
and the name of the entity operating the concession. A "concession contract," for purposes of this subsection,
shall mean an agreement or arrangement where the person selling alcoholic beverages is doing so as a
department or section of a larger business enterprise, for example, a beverage service operated within a hotel,
food and beverage services operated within an indoor commercial recreational establishment or outdoor
commercial recreational establishment, or a beverage service operated within an eating establishment. For
purposes of determining whether a particular business enterprise qualifies as an eating establishment, hotel,
indoor commercial recreational establishment or an outdoor commercial recreational establishment, the
activities, facilities and sales of the business enterprise as a whole shall be aggregated, and the individual sales or
facilities of any concession therein shall not be treated separately.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-148. - Application procedure.
(a)
A person desiring to obtain a license under this article shall make application to the city clerk on the forms
prescribed by the city clerk.
(b)
The application shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
(1)
The name and address of the applicant and the proposed business to be carried on;
(2)
If a partnership, the names and residence addresses of all of the partners unless there are more than twenty (20)
partners, in which case the application shall list all partners having, directly or indirectly, at least a five-percent
interest in the assets or revenues of the partnership;
(3)
If a corporation, the names and residence addresses of the officers, the directors, the registered agent for service
of process, the manager of the business for which the license is sought and all shareholders unless there are more
than twenty (20) shareholders, in which case the application shall list all shareholders holding at least five (5)
percent of the capital stock of the corporation; and
(4)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
52/414
If a private club, the names and residence addresses of the officers, directors and the manager of such private
club.
(c)
All applicants shall furnish data, fingerprints, evidence of financial responsibility in the form of a bond in the
amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or insurance with a minimum coverage of one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000.00) per person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per incident, a copy of the
current city business license for the establishment, certification from the tax commissioner that all taxes due to
the city and county by the applicant have been paid and other material as required by the city clerk. Failure to
furnish such data as required by the city clerk shall be deemed to be a withdrawal of the application.
(d)
Each application for an initial license as opposed to a license renewal shall have attached thereto a plat of the
land on which the establishment is proposed to be located showing the location of the improvements thereon.
Such plat must be prepared by a land surveyor registered under the laws of the state and the surveyor shall show
on the plat and certify as to the accuracy thereof the distance from the main entrance door of the proposed
establishment to any school building, church building, city park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility
located within five hundred (500) yards thereof measured under the applicable provisions of section 3-152
(e)
All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to
administer oaths.
(f)
An application shall be presented to the city council or a committee designated by the city council within fortyfive (45) days after the date such application is deemed complete by the city clerk. The city clerk shall notify the
applicant in writing of the date on which the application will be presented to the city council or its designated
committee, which notice shall be given in sufficient time to enable the applicant to meet the public notice
requirements as set forth in section 3-151
(g)
At the time the application is presented to the city council or its designated committee, the applicant may appear
and present any matters in support of the application and any other person may appear and present matters in
opposition to the application. Upon hearing all of the presentations, the city council or its designated committee
shall take action denying or granting the application or deferring action for a period not to exceed forty-five (45)
days in order to obtain further information. If the application is denied, the city council or its designated
committee shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for the denial.
(h)
In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this article, the applicant may not
reapply for a similar license for the same location for at least one (1) year from the date of such denial.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-149. - Withdrawal of application; refund of fees.
Any application for a license made pursuant to this article may be withdrawn by the applicant at any time. If the
application is withdrawn before the license is issued, any sums deposited as license fees will be refunded. After
issuance of a license, no refunds will be made. No refunds shall be made under any circumstances for
investigation and administrative fees required in this article.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
53/414
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-150. - Licensing qualifications.
(a)
A license under this article will be issued only to a person who is a citizen of the United States or an alien
lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States. Where an applicant is other than a natural
person, such applicant must be an entity organized and existing under the laws of the United States or one (1) of
its states, and the natural persons who are required to join in the application must meet the qualifications of this
subsection.
(b)
For a license to be issued to a general partnership, the application must be made jointly by the partnership, any
managing partner and all other partners owning at least a twenty-percent interest in the assets or revenues of the
partnership. If there is no managing partner, nor a partner meeting the ownership requirements, the application
then must be made jointly in the name of the partnership and the general partner owning the greatest percentage
interest in the assets and revenues of the partnership. At least one (1) of the applicants shall be a natural person.
If none of the applicants required in this subsection is a natural person, then the natural person having primary
responsibility for the operation of the business for which the license is sought shall join in the application.
(c)
Where the applicant for a license is a limited partnership, the application shall be made jointly by the limited
partnership, its general partner and any other partner, limited or general, owning at least a twenty-percent interest
in the assets or revenues of the limited partnership. At least one (1) of the applicants must be a natural person. If
none of the applicants required in this subsection is a natural person, then the natural person having primary
responsibility for the operation of the business for which the license is sought shall join in the application.
(d)
Where the applicant for a license is a corporation, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the
corporation and its president or vice-president and any stockholder owning at least twenty (20) percent of the
total outstanding capital stock of the corporation.
(e)
Where the applicant for a license is a private club, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the private
club and its president or general manager.
(f)
Where the applicant for a license is an entity other than a natural person, partnership, corporation or private club,
the application shall be made jointly in the name of the entity, the natural person having chief executive officer
authority over the business activities of the entity and any other person having at least a five-percent interest in
the assets or revenues of the entity. The application shall further disclose the type of entity making the
application and every person having an ownership interest in the assets or revenues of the entity.
(g)
Licenses issued to corporations, general partnerships, limited partnerships, private clubs or other types of entities
must be issued jointly to the entity and all of the other persons required by this section to join in the application.
(h)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
54/414
No person shall be granted a license unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the city council or its designated
committee that such person shall be of good moral character or, in the case of an entity which is not a natural
person, that such entity has a good reputation, and in no event shall a license be granted to any person who has
been convicted or has pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any charge involving a crime of moral
turpitude, gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or illegal possession of alcoholic
beverages within a period of ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of such application. In the case of a
partnership, corporation, private club or other business entity, a license shall not be issued to the partnership,
corporation, private club or other entity if any partner, officer, director, shareholder or other person required to be
listed on the application, even if such person is not required to be a joint applicant, cannot meet the requirements
as set forth in this subsection in the same manner as though such individual was the applicant. At the time an
application is submitted for a license, the applicant shall, by a duly sworn affidavit, certify that all of the
requirements of this section have been met by the applicant and the other persons required to be listed on the
application as set forth in this subsection. Should any person in whose name a license is issued or any person
whose name is required to be listed on the application for a license under this article, after the license has been
issued, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a charge involving a crime of moral turpitude,
gambling or illegal possession or sale of controlled substances or illegal possession of alcoholic beverages, the
license shall be immediately revoked and cancelled.
(i)
No license under this article shall be issued to any person convicted or pleading guilty or nolo contendere to any
charge under any federal, state or local law constituting a felony within ten (10) years prior to the date of the
filing of the application for such license.
(j)
No license under this article shall be issued to any person who has had any license issued under the police
powers of any city or county revoked within two (2) years prior to the filing of the application for a license under
this article.
(k)
The city council or its designated committee may decline to issue a license under this article when any person
having any ownership interest in or control over the land or building in which the establishment to be operated
pursuant to the license will be located does not meet the same character requirements as set forth in this section
for the licensee.
(l)
If a person in whose name a license under this article is issued is not a county resident, such person must appoint
and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required
or permitted by law or under this article may be served. The registered agent must be a resident of the county. If
the licensee is not a natural person, it will be required to appoint and maintain a registered agent in the county if
it does not have in the county any agent upon whom process can legally be served for such entity under the laws
of the state. The licensee shall file the name of such registered agent, along with the written consent to serve of
such agent, with the city clerk.
(m)
An application for a license under this article may be denied where it appears to the city council or its designated
committee that the applicant does not have adequate financial strength, adequate financial participation in the
proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended or is likely to
be a surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license under this article.
(n)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
55/414
The city council or its designated committee, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances
which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, the application or the proposed location of the
establishment. If, in the city council's or the committee's judgment, circumstances are such that issuing of a
license under this article would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be
grounds for denying the application.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-151. - Public notice of application for new license.
A person filing an application for a new license under this article as opposed to an application for the renewal of
an existing license shall give public notice of the filing of the application as follows:
(1)
By publishing a notice of the application in the newspaper in which sheriff's sales in the county are placed, in a
form approved by the city clerk, three (3) times in the thirty (30) days preceding the consideration of the
application by the city council;
(2)
By posting a sign for at least thirty (30) days preceding the consideration of the application by the city council in
a prominent position on the property where it can be readily read from the road, which states:
"Application has been made to the city council for a license to sell (beer) (wine) (distilled spirits) for
consumption (on) (off) premises at this location."
Date:
____________
Name of Applicant
____________ ____________
The applicant must provide the city council proof of the giving of such public notice at or prior to the city
council's consideration of the application.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-152. - Distance requirements.
(a)
No establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article shall be located in a building which is closer
than one hundred (100) yards to a church building, library, daycare, children's nursery, or an alcoholic treatment
facility, or closer than two hundred (200) yards to a school building. In applying this section, the city council
shall determine what property is included in a school building, church building, city park or playground, or
alcoholic treatment facility consistent with the definitions set forth in section 3-102, and the determination of the
city council shall be final.
(b)
For purposes of this section, subject to the qualifications set forth in this subsection, distances shall be measured
in a straight line from the main entrance door of the establishment for which the license under this article is being
sought to the nearest point on the boundary line of the land making up the campus of the church building, school
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
56/414
building, or alcoholic treatment facility. All lots and parcels of land bordering on Wrightsboro Road at the edge
of the city limits up to and including the intersection of Wrightsboro Road and Robinson Avenue is hereby
declared to be a "special commercial growth center" only for the purposes of complying with this article. As
such all distances from any church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility which is built,
acquired or established after December 31, 2002, or in the case of areas added to the designated areas which are
built, acquired or established after the effective date of such designation, distance shall be measured from the
main entrance door of the establishment for which a license is being sought to the nearest point of the centerline
of the nearest traveled road, street or highway, then measured along such centerline to a point on the centerline
nearest the main entrance door of the school building, church building, or alcoholic treatment facility and then
measured in a straight line from such centerline to such main entrance door. If any church building, school
building, or alcoholic treatment facility located in one (1) of the designated areas on December 31, 2002 or the
effective date of designation of an area added to the designated areas after December 31, 2002, as the case may
be, thereafter has added to its campus additional land, measurement of the distance requirements shall continue
to be made as provided in the first sentence of this subsection (b), but the land acquired after December 31, 2002,
or the effective designation date, as the case may be, shall not be considered to be part of the land or campus of
the church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility.
(c)
No establishment which is being operated pursuant to a city license to sell beer and/or wine on January 1, 2003,
the effective date of this article, shall be denied continued operation under such existing license, nor denied any
renewal of such license, nor shall any new owner of such establishment be denied a new license based upon the
measurements set forth in this section. Upon cessation of the operation of the establishment as set forth in section
3-156 pursuant to such license, such exemption shall cease.
(d)
If the distance requirements in this section are met at the time of issuance of a license under this article, the
subsequent opening and operation of a church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility within the
distances prohibited in this section shall not prevent the continued operation of the establishment pursuant to the
license or the renewal of the license or the issuance of a new license to any subsequent owner of such
establishment as long as the business operation of the establishment does not cease as set forth in section 3-156
(e)
The holder of title to any property making up a church building, school building, or alcoholic treatment facility
may waive the distance requirements of this section as they apply to such facility in any specific instance by
recording in the real estate records in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county, a written instrument
evidencing such waiver and setting out the terms thereof, which instrument shall be executed and witnessed with
the same formalities as a deed filed for record in the clerk's office.
(f)
Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city council from amending this section, adding additional special
commercial growth centers nor amending any distance requirements in the future.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-153. - Administrative and investigative fees.
(a)
Upon making application for a license under this article, the applicant shall pay a license fee for the license, an
administrative and investigative fee and such other fees as may be established from time to time by the city
council by resolution adopted in open meeting and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The initial schedule
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
57/414
of fees shall be adopted and is attached to the Alcoholic Beverage Control Ordinance adopted January 1, 2003.
Such schedule of fees shall remain in effect until amended by the city council. All applicants shall be furnished a
copy of the schedule of fees at the time of application for a license under this article. In addition, all fees and
taxes due the state, city, and/or county by the applicant, or upon the property on which the establishment is to be
located, must be paid in full at or prior to the time of filing the application for the license.
(b)
All licenses granted under this article shall be for a calendar year and the full license fee must be paid for a
license application at the time of the filing of the application.
(c)
Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of
the license fee, together with a separate certified check in the amount of the applicable investigate and
administrative fees. If the applicant is denied a state license, the deposit representing the license fee shall be
refunded, but the investigative and administrative fees shall be retained.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-154. - Display at place of business.
A license issued under this article shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to public view at the place of
business for which the license was granted.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-155. - Transferability.
(a)
No license under this article shall be transferable, except as otherwise provided in this section.
(b)
In case of the death of a licensee who is the sole licensee, the establishment for which the license was issued
shall be allowed to continue to sell alcoholic beverages in accordance with the terms of the license for a period of
forty-five (45) days from the date of death of the licensee or until approval of a new licensee, whichever shall
first occur; provided, however, that no sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed after the seventh day after the
date of death of the licensee until such time as a personal representative of the estate of the deceased licensee,
appointed by a probate court of competent jurisdiction, shall have registered with the city clerk on forms
prepared by the city clerk. Such personal representative shall be subject to all of the requirements that applied to
the deceased licensee, and shall agree in writing to operate the establishment during the interim period in
accordance with the terms of the license and the laws of the state and city.
(c)
In the case of licenses issued jointly to partnerships and certain partners, corporations and certain officers or
stockholders, private clubs and certain officers or other entities and certain persons related thereto as set forth in
section 3-150, if one (1) of the joint holders of such a license severs his association with the establishment
operated pursuant to the license, the establishment may continue to sell alcoholic beverages for a period of fortyfive (45) days from the date determined by the city clerk to be the date of severance, provided no such sale shall
be authorized until such time as an application to substitute the person taking the place of the departing person as
a joint holder of the license is made by the appropriate person. If the change is one which results from a change
in control of the licensee, partnership, corporation or other business entity, then an application for a new license
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
58/414
must be filed. Upon issuance of a new license, the authorization to sell under the previous license shall be
revoked by operation of law.
(d)
Any change in the ownership of a licensee which is not a natural person which would change the ownership
information furnished on the most recently updated application for the license must be reported to the city clerk
within ten (10) days following the occurrence of such change in ownership. If such change in ownership results
in an additional person being required to be a joint licensee under section 3-148, or an additional person being
listed on the application, but not as a joint licensee, the license may be revoked if any such person fails to meet
the qualifications required by this article. If such change in ownership results in a change in control of the
business entity which is a joint licensee, then a new application must be filed for the issuance of a new license. If
an application for a new license is filed within seven (7) days of the date on which the change in control
occurred, then the establishment may continue to operate under the old license for a period of forty-five (45)
days from the date of the change in control or until the new license is issued or denied, whichever shall occur
first.
(e)
If substantially all of the assets of an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article are sold,
conveyed or otherwise transferred by the licensee, and if an application for a new license is filed with the city
clerk within seven (7) days of such sale or transfer, the establishment may continue to be operated under the then
existing license for a period of forty-five (45) days or until a new license is issued or denied to the new owner,
whichever shall occur first.
(f)
Under no circumstances shall a license be transferred where the original holder of the license is under
suspension.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-156. - Automatic forfeiture for nonuse.
Any licensee who shall, for a period of two (2) consecutive months after the license under this article has been
issued, cease to operate the business of selling alcoholic beverages as authorized in the license shall, after the
two-month period, automatically forfeit the license without the necessity of any further action. If the business
operation of selling alcoholic beverages is interrupted as a result of damage to the premises which is being
repaired or because the premises is being remodeled, then this section shall not apply to such cessation of
operation. If a license is issued for the operation of an establishment in a building which has not yet been
completed, the license will not be forfeited unless the licensee fails to begin operations within a period of one
hundred eighty (180) days from the date of issuance of the license.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-157. - Expiration; renewal.
(a)
All licenses granted under this article shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew
their license shall file application with the city clerk on the form provided for renewal of the license for the
ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed on or before October 31 of each year. If a renewal
application is received after October 31, the city cannot assure the applicant that a renewal license will be issued
by January 1 and the licensee will have to cease the sale of alcoholic beverages from January 1 until the renewal
license is issued. If a license renewal application is received after December 31, such application shall be treated
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
59/414
as an application for a new license and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules, regulations and
fees for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been issued.
(b)
Any person applying for renewal of a license must pay the license, administrative and investigative fees at the
time of filing the application. Failure to pay such fees at that time shall result in the application for renewal being
treated as not filed or withdrawn.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-158. - Audits.
The city clerk, in order to determine if the provisions of this chapter are being complied with or to determine the
eligibility of an applicant, may require a licensee or an applicant for a license under this article to provide the
city clerk with audited financial statements of the licensee or applicant for such period as the city clerk may
determine. The city clerk shall also have the authority to conduct an audit of the books and records of a licensee
or an applicant. If the city clerk deems it necessary to conduct such an audit, the city clerk shall so notify the
licensee or applicant of the date, time and place of the audit. The city clerk shall designate the person to perform
such audit. The licensee shall cooperate with such audit or forfeit all licenses issued under this article. If an
applicant for a license fails to cooperate with an audit, the application shall be deemed withdrawn.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-159. - Collection of delinquent sums.
If any person shall fail to pay any sum due under this chapter, the city clerk or his/her designee shall issue an
execution against the delinquent person and his property for the amount of the delinquent fee or tax. The failure
to pay any taxes or fees shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and the license of the business to sell alcohol
shall be suspended immediately.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-160. - Licensee to maintain copies of regulations; responsibility for instruction; violations.
Each licensee shall keep a copy of this chapter, the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code and any regulations issued
under such code on the premises. The licensee shall instruct any employee or agent of the licensee working in
connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages as to the requirements of all laws and regulations applicable to
such sales so that the licensee, his agents and employees selling alcoholic beverages shall at all times be familiar
with the requirements of the laws and regulations applicable to such sales. The licensee shall be responsible for
any acts of his agents or employees which are in violation of this chapter or of the laws of the state or the rules
and regulations of the state revenue commissioner applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-161. - Suspension, revocation.
(a)
A license under this article may be suspended or revoked by the city council when the licensee furnishes
fraudulent or untruthful information on the application or any renewal application for a license, or for failure of
the licensee to pay all fees, taxes or other charges imposed under the provisions of this chapter or other laws or
ordinances of the city or state.
(b)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
60/414
Whenever the state shall revoke or suspend any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the license issued
under this article shall be automatically revoked or suspended, as the case may be.
(c)
If the city clerk, the city council or its designated committee believes that probable cause exists to find that a
violation of sections 3-106, 3-188 and/or 3-194 has occurred in an establishment operated pursuant to a license
under this article, the city council or its designated committee may temporarily suspend such license pending
final determination and action on the matter by the city council or its designated committee.
(d)
The city clerk shall revoke all of the licenses of any licensee under this article who has had three or more
suspensions or revocations of a license, including all of his licenses in any consecutive thirty-six-month period.
(e)
The city clerk shall revoke a license under this article where alcoholic beverages have been sold or distributed at
the location covered by the license during a period of suspension of such license.
(f)
The city council may suspend or revoke any license under this article when the licensee does not meet the
licensing qualifications set forth in this article and such information becomes known to the city clerk or the city
council.
(g)
An act or omission of a licensee under this article, by the owner of a twenty (20) percent or more interest in an
establishment operated pursuant to a license, the manager of an establishment operated pursuant to a license or
an employee of the establishment operated pursuant to a license working in some aspect of the sale of alcoholic
beverages who willingly or knowingly performed any act, which constitutes a violation of federal or state law or
this chapter will subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of his license when the city council determines
that the act or omission did occur, regardless of whether any criminal prosecution or conviction ensues;
provided, however, that in the case of a manager or employee, the city council must determine that the acts of the
manager or employee were known to or, under reasonable circumstances, should have been known to the
licensee, or were condoned by the licensee, or that the licensee had not established reasonable practices or
procedures to prevent such act or omission from occurring.
(h)
A license under this article may be suspended or revoked whenever the city council determines that a licensee no
longer maintains adequate financial strength or responsibility upon which issuance of the license was based or
whenever the licensee has defaulted in any obligation of any kind whatsoever lawfully owing to the city.
(i)
A license under this article may be suspended or revoked whenever the city council determines that the
establishment operated pursuant to the license has been the scene of repeated incidents of violence resulting in
injury to a person or damage to property or a disturbance of the peace or requiring the intervention of law
enforcement officers on the scene of a single incident of severe violence resulting in the death of a person or
serious injury to a person requiring inpatient hospital care for the injured person.
(j)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
61/414
Upon completion of any period of suspension, a license under this article shall not be reinstated until the licensee
has paid the city a reinstatement fee equal to the original license fee for that calendar year. In addition, the
licensee shall pay the administrative and investigative fees and update all license application forms.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-162. - Hearings.
(a)
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, or unless waived by the licensee, no license under this article shall be
suspended or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section.
(b)
The city clerk shall provide written notice to the licensee of the initiation of an action to suspend or revoke a
license. Such written notification shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for such action and shall notify
the licensee of the right to a hearing under the provisions of this section. Any licensee against whom action for
the suspension or revocation of a license is initiated may have a hearing concerning such action before the city
council or a committee thereof designated by the city council. Such hearing shall be by written request, filed in
the office of the city clerk within twenty (20) days after the date of the notice of the initiation of the action from
the city clerk to the licensee. Such written request shall set forth the reasons why the licensee feels that the
proposed action should not be taken and, in reasonable detail, the grounds and facts which the licensee contends
support the licensee's position. The city council shall determine whether or not the license shall be temporarily
suspended during the period prior to the hearing and until action is taken by the city council or its designated
committee. Failure of the licensee to request a hearing within the time specified shall be deemed to be a waiver
by the licensee of a right to a hearing, and the city council shall be authorized to proceed with final action on the
matter without the holding of a hearing.
(c)
The city council, by resolution, may assign the duties of conducting a hearing to a committee of the city council.
The committee's action shall be final.
(d)
A hearing, if requested, shall be held within forty-five (45) days of the date of filing the request for a hearing
with the city clerk. At such hearing the licensee shall have the right to be represented by an attorney, at the
expense of the licensee, and to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses.
(e)
The action of the city council or its committee shall be forwarded to the city clerk within fifteen (15) days after
the conclusion of the hearing, and the city clerk shall notify the licensee by certified mail, return receipt
requested, of the action taken by the city council or its committee.
(f)
The action of the city council or its committee shall be final when taken.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-163. - Notice.
For the purpose of this chapter, notice shall be deemed to be delivered when such notice is personally served,
served upon the licensee's registered agent, or, if mailed, it must be mailed to the licensee at the address given in
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
62/414
the latest application for the license under this article by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall be
deemed delivered on the third business day after the date of deposit in the United States mail.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Secs. 3-164—3-185. - Reserved.
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS REGULATIONS
Sec. 3-186. - Outdoor advertising.
(a)
No outdoor advertising or signs promoting the sale of alcoholic beverages or the prices thereof shall be permitted
on the premises of any establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article.
(b)
Wholesale dealers may place wall-mounted signs on the principal building advertising the name of the company
and brands sold at wholesale. Such signs must otherwise comply with city ordinances regulating signs.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-187. - Sale of beverages by indoor and outdoor commercial recreational establishments.
(a)
A retail consumption dealer which is an indoor commercial recreational establishment shall not sell alcoholic
beverages at any time that such dealer is having a promotion or event for which it can reasonably be anticipated
that in excess of fifty (50) percent of those persons attending will be under twenty-one (21) years of age.
(b)
A retail consumption dealer which is an outdoor commercial recreational establishment shall not sell alcoholic
beverages at any time that such dealer is having a promotion or event for which it can reasonably be anticipated
that in excess of fifty (50) percent of those persons attending will be under twenty-one (21) years of age.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-188. - Gambling prohibited on the premises of retail consumption dealers.
There shall be no gambling, betting, lotteries, games of chance or the operation of any scheme for hazarding
money or any other thing of value on the premises of any retail consumption dealer. No retail consumption
dealer shall permit in his establishment slot machines, pinball machines or similar machines which require a
federal gambling stamp. Notwithstanding anything in this division to the contrary, this section shall not prohibit
the sale on the premises of any retail consumption dealer of state lottery tickets, cards or games which are legally
sold under the laws of the state.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-189. - Open area and patio sales.
(a)
Alcoholic beverage sales can be made by a retail consumption dealer in a patio/open area type environment if the
retail consumption dealer has been approved to do so by the city clerk.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
63/414
(b)
To obtain such approval, the patio/open area must be enclosed by a permanent structure providing for public
ingress/egress only through the main structure on the premises covered by the license. The purpose of this
requirement is to prevent a customer from leaving the outside sales area with an open drink container without the
licensee's knowledge.
(c)
The height of the enclosing structure shall be a minimum of four (4) feet above ground level. Such enclosing
structure does not have to be solid, nor does it have to restrict visibility into or out of the patio/open sales area.
Such enclosing structure must be permitted and approved by the engineering services department.
(d)
There must be an approved emergency fire exit (not for general public use unless an emergency exists) from the
patio/open sales area which should be of the type that sounds an alarm so that the licensee will be alerted in the
event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists.
(e)
If a licensee desires a patio/open sales area inside an existing structure, plans will be reviewed and approved on
an individual basis by the city clerk. Interior-type patio/open sales areas must also meet the requirements of the
city's planning, zoning, engineering and fire codes, and any applicable codes of the state.
(f)
Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, if the retail consumption dealer is an outdoor
commercial recreational establishment, alcoholic beverage sales can be made outdoors in the open, provided that
such alcoholic beverages must be consumed on the premises of the outdoor commercial recreational
establishment and may not be carried off of such premises.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-190. - Outside consumption prohibited; exception.
(a)
No person shall leave the building in which alcoholic beverages are sold with open alcoholic beverage containers
unless such person is in a patio/open sales area which is approved in accordance with section 3-189. It is the
licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open alcoholic beverage containers are carried out of the building in
violation of this section.
(b)
People shall not gather outside any building in which alcoholic beverages are sold and consume alcoholic
beverages or loiter and mill about. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee operating the business in such
building to prevent such gatherings.
(c)
Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, a person purchasing an alcoholic beverage at an outdoor
commercial recreational establishment which is a retail consumption dealer may leave the building in which such
alcoholic beverage is sold and may consume such alcoholic beverage outdoors or may purchase and consume
such alcoholic beverage outdoors, provided that the alcoholic beverage must be consumed on the premises of the
outdoor commercial recreational establishment and may not be carried off of such premises.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
64/414
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-191. - Solicitation.
A retail consumption dealer shall not require, permit, suffer, encourage or induce any employee or person to
solicit on the premises, for himself or for any person other than the patron and guest of the patron, the purchase
by the patron of any drink, whether an alcoholic beverage or nonalcoholic beverage.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-192. - Happy hours or similar promotions.
(a)
No retail consumption dealer, his employees or agents, in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages, shall:
(1)
Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any person;
(2)
Deliver more than one (1) alcoholic beverage to one (1) person at a time;
(3)
Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished to any person an unlimited number of alcoholic beverages
during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public;
(4)
Increase the volume of alcohol contained in a drink without proportionately increasing the price regularly
charged for such alcoholic beverage;
(5)
Encourage or permit on the premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or
the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize; and
(6)
Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished any alcoholic beverages for a price less than the cost of the
ingredients to the licensee.
(b)
No retail consumption dealer shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the premises, any
of the practices prohibited under subsection (a) of this section.
(c)
Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit retail consumption dealers from offering free food or
entertainment at any time, or to prohibit the retail consumption dealer from including an alcoholic beverage as
part of a meal package, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe, or pitchers or buckets of
beer.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
65/414
Sec. 3-193. - Restriction of noise.
Noise levels above those otherwise allowed by city ordinances shall not be permitted beyond the boundaries of
the land on which facilities operated pursuant to a license under this article are located.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-194. - Certain types of entertainment, attire and conduct prohibited.
The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are not permitted in or at any establishment operating
pursuant to a license under this article:
(1)
The employment or use of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages while such
person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the female breast
below the top of the areola, or of any portion of a person's pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva or
genitals;
(2)
Live entertainment where any person appears in the manner set forth in subsection (1) of this section, or where
any person performs acts of or acts which simulate:
a.
Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are
prohibited by law;
b.
The touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals; or
c.
The displaying of any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, or any portion of a person's pubic
hair, anus, vulva or genitals.
(3)
The use of artificial devices or inanimate objects to perform, simulate or depict any of the prohibited conduct or
activities set forth in subsection (2) of this section, or the showing of any film, still pictures, electronic
reproduction or other visual reproductions depicting any of the acts set forth in subsection (2) of this section; or
(4)
The holding, promotion or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night or any other activity where patrons
of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the prohibited conduct set forth in
this section.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-195. - Inspection of licensed establishments.
Officers of the department of public safety and health department and the fire marshal shall have the authority to
inspect an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article during the hours in which the
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
66/414
establishment is open for business. Such inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with
the requirements of this chapter and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other city
officer to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of this Code.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-196. - Closing establishment in case of emergency.
The director of the department of public safety or the city clerk, or their designees, may immediately close an
establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article in case of an emergency, for the safety of the
public or to investigate a crime for a period of time not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours, or for such longer
period of time as law enforcement officials may reasonably require to complete a criminal investigation at the
establishment.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-197. - Bringing alcoholic beverages into establishments.
No person shall bring his own alcoholic beverages into any commercial establishment regardless of whether or
not such establishment is operated pursuant to a license under this article.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-198. - Consumption on-premises of distilled spirits; locations where permitted.
A license for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises will be issued only for an
eating establishment, a hotel, an indoor or outdoor commercial recreational establishment or a private club.
When eating establishments are located in hotels, shopping malls or high-rise office or apartment buildings,
every public entrance to the eating establishment shall be from the outside or a public lobby, hallway, mall or
other publicly used interior portion of the primary use structure.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-199. - Hours and days of sale of distilled spirits.
(a)
Distilled spirits shall not be sold for consumption on the premises, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. until
1:55 a.m. on Monday through Saturday morning at 1:55 a.m. and from 9:00 a.m. Saturday until 11:55 p.m. on
Saturday. The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on premises is permitted on Sundays from 12:30 p.m.
until 12:00 midnight in any licensed establishment which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual
gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual
establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least fifty (50) percent of
its total gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging.
(b)
Distilled spirits shall not be sold for consumption on the premises at any time in violation of any local ordinance
or regulation, or of any special order of the city council.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02; Ord. No. 173-02, § 1, 2-12-06)
Sec. 3-200. - Consumption sales only of distilled spirits.
Persons holding a license to sell distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted to make
any package sales of alcoholic beverages on such premises.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
67/414
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-201. - Drinks to be served by employees.
Alcoholic beverages sold by the drink must be served by employees of the licensee within the premises covered
by the license.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-202. - Storage of inventory.
A retail consumption dealer must keep his inventory of alcoholic beverages only on the premises covered by his
license.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-203. - Beer and wine consumption on-premises; locations where permitted.
No license for the sale of beer or wine for consumption on the premises will be issued, except for an eating
establishment, a hotel, an indoor or outdoor commercial recreational establishment or a private club.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-204. - Hours and days of sale of beer and wine for on-premises consumption.
(a)
Beer and wine shall not be sold for consumption on the premises, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. until
1:55 a.m. on Monday through Saturday morning at 1:55 a.m. and from 9:00 a.m. Saturday until 11:55 p.m. on
Saturday.
(b)
No beer and/or wine shall be sold for consumption on the premises at any time in violation of any local
ordinance or regulation, or of any special order of the city council.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-205. - Temporary permit for nonprofit civic organizations requirements.
Upon filing an application and paying the requisite fees, a nonprofit civic organization may be issued a
temporary permit authorizing the organization to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises for a
period not to exceed two (2) days. No more than two (2) temporary permits, covering a total of four (4) days,
shall be issued to an organization in any calendar year. Nonprofit organizations shall comply with all
requirements of this chapter for operations by a retail consumption dealer, except that the alcoholic beverages
may be included in the price of admission to the event, no excise taxes shall be paid or collected on such sales,
and such other exceptions as the city clerk or the city council or its designated committee may approve. No
public notice of the application shall be required for any temporary permit. An application for a temporary
permit under this section must be filed not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date for which the temporary
permit is sought. Such application shall be made on forms prescribed by the city clerk and shall contain all
information required by such forms. The chief executive officer and chief operating officer of the organization
must be joint applicants for the temporary permit. All applications for temporary permits under this section must
be approved by the city council or its designated committee, who shall have the authority to determine if the
applicant is a nonprofit civic organization, and such determination in this regard shall be final.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
68/414
Sec. 3-206. - Package sales.
Package sales of malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits shall be allowed on Sunday between the hours of
12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m.
(Ord. No. 215, 12-12-11)
Secs. 3-207—3-213. - Reserved.
Sec. 3-214. - Wholesale purchase of distilled spirits, beer and wine.
(a)
No retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer shall purchase any alcoholic beverage from any person
other than a wholesaler. No wholesaler shall sell any alcoholic beverage to any person other than a retail
consumption dealer or retail package dealer; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the purchase
by one retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer of another retail consumption dealer's or retail package
dealer's entire stock in a bona fide purchase of an ongoing business.
(b)
No alcoholic beverage shall be delivered to any retail sales outlet in the city, except by a wholesaler. The name of
the wholesaler shall be clearly marked on the delivery vehicle.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-215. - Reserved.
Sec. 3-216. - Hotel in-room service.
(a)
Definition. As used in this section, "in-room service" means the delivery of alcoholic beverages, in unbroken
packages, by an employee of a hotel to a registered guest's room when such alcoholic beverages have been
ordered by the guest, and the guest will be billed for such alcoholic beverages at the time of delivery, and when
the sale of such alcoholic beverages is completed at the time of delivery; and the provision of a cabinet or other
facility located in a hotel's guest room which contains alcoholic beverages and which is provided upon written
request of the guest, and which is accessible by lock and key only to the guest, and for which the sale of the
alcoholic beverages contained in such cabinet or other facility is final at the time requested, except for a credit
which may be given to the guest for any unused portion.
(b)
License. A hotel, if it has a license to sell alcoholic beverages either by the package and/or by the drink, may be
authorized by the city council to make similar sales through in-room service. A hotel, prior to providing in-room
service, must obtain from the city a license permitting such hotel to provide in-room service of alcoholic
beverages.
(c)
Restrictions and limitations. The sale of alcoholic beverages by in-room service shall be subject to all restrictions
and limitations of this chapter relative to the retail sale of alcoholic beverages, except as provided otherwise in
this section, and shall be authorized only on such days and during such hours as the sale of the alcoholic
beverages in question is otherwise authorized in the city.
(d)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
69/414
Package size. Distilled spirits sold through in-room service shall not be sold in packages containing less than two
hundred (200) milliliters each.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-217. - Certain government facilities.
Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, the city council may permit the sale of alcoholic
beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises at such city-owned facilities and under such conditions
as the city council may determine from time to time.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Secs. 2-218—2-250. - Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAXES
FOOTNOTE(S):
(6) State Law reference— Authority to impose excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-
4-13o; imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80.
Sec. 3-251. - Retail sales of distilled spirits by the drink.
Every purchaser at retail of distilled spirits by the drink in the city shall pay a tax thereon at the rate of three (3)
percent of the retail price or charge for such drink, or at such higher rate as may be permitted by the laws of the
state. Such tax shall not apply in any portion of the city in which an excise tax on the sale of distilled spirits by
the drink is being imposed, levied and collected by a municipality. Such tax shall be collected by the retail
consumption dealer, who shall remit such tax to the city clerk on or before the tenth day of the following
calendar month, along with a report of the retail consumption dealer's gross sales derived from the sale of
distilled spirits by the drink during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk. Credit card sales
shall be reported as part of gross sales, and taxes collected on such credit card sales shall be submitted to the city
in the same manner as required for cash sales. Each retail consumption dealer shall be allowed a deduction equal
to the rate authorized for deductions from state tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50, as amended from time to time,
provided that such tax is not delinquent at the time of payment.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-252. - Wholesale sales of distilled spirits and wine.
There is levied an excise tax computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter, including a proportionate amount calculated
at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter, on all sales of distilled spirits and wine in the city by wholesalers
to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers. Such tax shall be paid to the city clerk by the wholesaler
selling such distilled spirits or wine to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the
tenth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of distilled spirits
and wine in the city during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk. Wine containing less than
one-half (½) of one (1) percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. It shall be a violation of this
chapter for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver, in any manner, any distilled spirits or wine to a retail
consumption dealer or retail package dealer without collecting such tax. It shall be unlawful and a violation of
this chapter for any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell
any distilled spirits or wine on which such tax has not been paid. Each wholesaler shall be paid three (3) percent
of the amount of taxes collected as reimbursement for collection of the tax, provided that the tax is paid on or
before its due date.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
70/414
Sec. 3-253. - Wholesale sales of beer.
There is levied an excise tax on all beer sold by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package
dealers in the city at the highest rate allowed by the state, but not less than the following:
(1)
Where beer is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, six dollars ($6.00) on each container sold containing not
more than fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of
fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons; and
(2)
Where beer is sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of five cents ($0.05)
per twelve (12) ounces, and a proportionate rate on all fractional parts of twelve (12) ounces.
Beer which contains less than one-half (½) of one (1) percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax.
Such tax shall be paid to the city clerk by the wholesaler selling the beer to any retail consumption dealer or
retail package dealer on or before the tenth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the
wholesaler's gross sales of beer in the city during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the city clerk.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-254. - Deficiency determination.
(a)
Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return
of the tax or the amount of the tax to be paid to the city by any person, the city clerk may cause an audit of the
books and records of the licensee to be performed and may compute and determine the amount required to be
paid upon the basis of any information within the city clerk's possession or that may come into the city clerk's
possession. One (1) or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more
monthly periods. It shall be the duty of each licensee subject to the collection or payment of any of the excise
taxes set forth in this article to keep and preserve his records relative to the collection and payment of such taxes
for three (3) years.
(b)
Interest. The amount of the deficiency determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one
(1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the tenth day after the close of the monthly period in which the
amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment thereof.
(c)
Offsetting of overpayments. In making a deficiency determination, the city clerk may offset overpayments for a
period against underpayments for another period, penalties and the interest on underpayments.
(d)
Penalty for negligence or disregard of rules and regulations. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency
determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty of fifteen (15)
percent of the amount of such deficiency shall be added to the tax.
(e)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
71/414
Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination is made is
due to fraud or an intent to evade any provision of sections 3-251—3-256, or other authorized rules and
regulations, a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the deficiency shall be added to such tax.
(f)
Notice of city clerk's determination; service of. The city clerk or his designated representative shall give to the
licensee written notice of a deficiency determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If such
service is made by mail, such service shall be made pursuant to section 3-163
(g)
Time within which notice is to be mailed. Except in the case of fraud, intent to evade the provisions of this article
or authorized rules and regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall
be mailed within three (3) years after the tenth day of every month following the monthly period for which the
amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last
expire.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-255. - Determination if no return made.
(a)
Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the
amount of the gross receipts of the licensee or of the total sales in the city which are subject to the tax. The
estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based
upon any information which is in or may come into the possession of the city clerk. Upon the basis of such
estimate, the city clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city, adding to such
determined sum a penalty equal to fifteen (15) percent thereof. One (1) or more determinations may be made for
one (1) or more periods.
(b)
Offsetting of overpayments. If making a determination, the city clerk may offset overpayments for a period or
penalties against the interest on the underpayments.
(c)
Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the
rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the tenth day of the month following the monthly
period for which the amount, or any portion thereof, should have been returned, until the date of payment.
(d)
Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. If the failure of any person to file a return is due to fraud or an intent to
evade sections 3-251—3-256 or rules and regulations, a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the amount
required to be paid by the person, exclusive of penalties, shall be added thereto in addition to the fifteen (15)
percent penalty provided in section 3-254(d).
(e)
Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his determination, the city clerk shall give to the
person written notice, to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice in section
3-163
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
72/414
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Sec. 3-256. - Collection.
(a)
Security. Whenever the city clerk deems it necessary to ensure compliance with sections 3-251—3-256, he may
require any person subject to such sections to deposit with him such security as the city clerk may determine.
The amount of the security shall be fixed by the city clerk, but shall not be greater than twice the person's
estimated average liability for the period for which he files returns, determined in such a manner as the city clerk
deems proper, or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), whichever amount is the lesser. The amount of the security
may be increased by the city clerk subject to the limitations provided in this section. The city clerk may sell the
security at public auction, with the approval of the city council, if it becomes necessary to do so in order to
recover any tax or any amount required to be collected, interest or penalty due. Notice of the sale may be served
upon the person who deposited the security personally or by mail. If service is by mail, it shall be made in the
manner prescribed for service of a notice of determined deficiency and shall be addressed to the person at his
address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. Upon any sale, any surplus above the amounts due shall be
returned to the person who deposited the security.
(b)
Notice of delinquency to persons holding credits or property of delinquent; duty of persons so notified. If any
person is delinquent in the payment of the amount required to be paid by him, or if a delinquency determination
has been made against him which remains unpaid, the city clerk may, not later than three (3) years after the
payment became delinquent, give notice thereof by registered mail to all persons in the city having in their
possession or under their control any credits or other personal property belonging to the delinquent, or owing any
debts to the delinquent. After receiving the notice, the persons so notified shall neither transfer nor make any
other disposition of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession or under their control at the
time they receive the notice until the city clerk consents to a transfer or disposition, or until twenty (20) days
elapse after the receipt of the notice. All persons so notified shall, within five (5) days after receipt of the notice,
advise the city clerk of all of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession, under their control
or owing by them.
(c)
Action for tax collection. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be
collected under this article becomes due and payable, and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency
of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article, the city clerk may bring an action in
the courts of this state, any other state or of the United States in the name of city to collect the amount
delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident
thereto.
(d)
Duty of successors or assignees of licensee to withhold tax from purchase money. If any licensee liable for any
amount under sections 3-251—3-256 sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall
withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a
receipt from the city clerk showing that he has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due.
(e)
Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the
purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the
payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price valued in money.
Within thirty (30) days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the city clerk shall
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
73/414
either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address, as it appears on the records of the city
clerk, of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the
obligation of the successor may be enforced shall begin at the time the licensee sells out his business or at the
time that the determination against the licensee becomes final, whichever occurs later.
(f)
Refund of tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax,
penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the
city under sections 3-251—3-256, it may be offset as provided in section 3-254(c) or it may be refunded
provided a verified claim in writing therefor, stating the specific grounds upon which the claim is founded, is
filed with the city clerk within three (3) years from the date of payment. The claim shall be audited and shall be
made on forms provided by the city clerk. If the claim is approved by the city clerk and the city council, the
excess amount collected or paid may be refunded or may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from
the person from whom it was collected or by whom paid, and the balance may be refunded to such person, his
administrators or executors.
(g)
The city council or its designated committee may decline to issue a license under this article when any person
having any ownership interest in or control over the land or building in which the establishment to be operated
pursuant to the license will be located does not meet the same character requirements as set forth in this section
for the licensee.
(h)
If a person in whose name a license under this article is issued is not a county resident, such person must appoint
and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required
or permitted by law or under this article may be served. The registered agent must be a resident of the county. If
the licensee is not a natural person, it will be required to appoint and maintain a registered agent in the county if
it does not have in the county any agent upon whom process can legally be served for such entity under the laws
of the state. The licensee shall file the name of such registered agent, along with the written consent to serve of
such agent, with the city clerk.
(i)
An application for a license under this article may be denied where it appears to the city council or its designated
committee that the applicant does not have adequate financial strength, adequate financial participation in the
proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended or is likely to
be a surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license under this article.
(j)
The city council or its designated committee, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances
which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, the application or the proposed location of the
establishment. If, in the city council's or the committee's judgment, circumstances are such that issuing of a
license under this article would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be
grounds for denying the application.
(Ord. No. 147, 11-11-02)
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL
FOOTNOTE(S):
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
74/414
