ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions.
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them:
Animal: Any member of the family "animalis."
At large: Off of the property of the animal's owner, unless under control of the owner or within a vehicle being
driven or parked on the streets or highways of the city.
Attack dog: A dog which has been trained in any manner to attack persons or animals upon command.
Cat: Any animal classified as "felis libyca domestica."
Control: An animal shall be deemed to be under control when it is controlled by a leash or other physical
attachment or is within the property limits of its owner or beside a competent person and obedient to such
person's command or is in a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets or highways of the city or is in the rear
of a pickup or open truck and controlled by a leash or other physical attachment.
Dangerous dog: Any dog that, according to the records of animal control:
(1)
Inflicts a severe injury on a human without provocation on public or private property at any time after March 31,
1989; or
(2)
Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been
classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification.
Dog: Any animal classified as "canis familars."
Dog control officer: An individual selected under this Code or under provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c) to aid in
the administration and enforcement of this chapter and applicable state law.
Guard-security dog: A dog which has been trained or is used for guard and/or security purposes.
Inoculation: The administration of antirabic vaccine, approved by the board of health of the county, administered
by a licensed veterinarian or other person approved and authorized by such board of health to administer
inoculations.
Kennel, city: Three (3) or more dogs six (6) months or older. (See the zoning ordinance for more complete
detail.)
Kennel or pound, county: Any premises designated by the animal control department for the purpose of
impounding and caring for dogs and other animals found at large in violation of this chapter.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
75/414
Livestock: Any animal of the equine, bovine, or swine class, including goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle,
and other grazing animals.
Owner: Any person as defined in section 1-2, specifically including but not limited to an individual, corporation,
partnership, firm, or trust owner, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dog,
dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or any other animal within the city.
Potentially dangerous dog: Any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property
at any time after March 31, 1989.
Proper enclosure: An enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's
property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence, or structure suitable to
prevent the entry of young children or other individuals and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any
such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides
of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a
manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also
provide protection from the elements for the dog. A symbol indicating a dangerous dog will be posted clearly
(see section 4-42, Figure 1).
Records of an appropriate authority: Records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency;
records of any county, or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any
federal, state, or local court; or records of a dog control officer provided for in this chapter.
Severe injury: Any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple
sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death.
Vicious animal: A savagely aggressive, or dangerous, animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to
attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of human beings.
State law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-3-2, 4-8-21.
Sec. 4-2. - Violation; penalties.
(a)
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with any requirement hereof shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a first offense, not less than
two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not more than four hundred dollars ($400.00) for a second offense, and not
less than four hundred dollars ($400.00) and not more than six hundred dollars ($600.00) for a third offense, or
imprisoned in the county jail for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, and in addition shall pay the cost of such
action.
(b)
If a person who has three (3) previous convictions for a violation of this chapter knowingly and wilfully fails to
comply with any provision hereof, charges against such person shall be referred to the district attorney for
prosecution.
(Ord. No. 88, §§ 19, 30, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-3. - Redemption of impounded animals—Procedure; fees.
Any animal impounded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be reclaimed, except as provided herein
for dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs, by its owner by payment of a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for
the first impoundment, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the second impoundment, and thirty-five dollars ($35.00)
for the third impoundment, and fifty dollars ($50.00) for the fourth impoundment, and one hundred dollars
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
76/414
($100.00) for each impoundment thereafter, plus a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day of
impoundment. Any animal which is not reclaimed by its owner within five (5) days pursuant to section 4-4 may
be adopted by payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). In the event that such reclaimed or adopted animal is
required by law to be vaccinated or inoculated, such person reclaiming or adopting such animal shall reimburse
the city for the cost of such vaccinations and inoculations. The animal control department shall cause such
animals to be vaccinated or inoculated at the expense of the person reclaiming or adopting such animal.
(Ord. No. 88, § 11, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-4. - Same—Disposition of unreclaimed animal.
Any animal impounded under the provisions of this chapter which is not reclaimed within ten (10) days by its
owner may be disposed of in a recognized humane manner by the animal control department, or placed in the
custody of some person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner and who shall agree to comply with the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 88, § 12, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-5. - Liability of city and employees.
(a)
In the operation and enforcement of this chapter, the city assumes no liability or responsibility for the
enforcement or nonenforcement of this chapter. By owning or maintaining such animals in the city, the owner or
possessor of such animal consents to the operation of and enforcement of this chapter. By operation and
enforcement of this chapter, the city makes no representation upon which members of the public may rely for
their safety.
(b)
The city officers and employees, and other delegated persons of the animal control, shall not be liable for any
injury to any animal picked up as a result of a violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 88, §§ 16, 29(G), 35, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-6. - Abandonment of animals.
(a)
No person shall release an animal on any property, public or private, with the intention of abandoning the animal.
(b)
No person shall intentionally abandon a dead animal on any private property belonging to another unless the
person so doing shall have first obtained permission from the owner of the property on which the animal is being
left.
(c)
No person shall abandon a dead animal on any public property or public right-of-way unless the place on which
the animal is being left is an approved sanitary landfill or other facility designated by the city as a public facility
for receiving trash or refuse.
(Ord. No. 88, § 28, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Abandonment of dead dogs, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-1.1, 4-8-2.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
77/414
Sec. 4-7. - Cruelty; neglect.
(a)
Prohibited: No person shall, by such person's act, omission or neglect, cause unjustifiable physical pain,
suffering or death to any living animal. This section does not apply to killing of animals raised for the purpose of
providing food, nor does it apply to any person who hunts wild animals in compliance with the game and fish
laws of this state. Killing or injuring an animal for humane purposes or in the furtherance of medical or scientific
research is justifiable.
(b)
Permitted acts: No person shall perform a cruel act on any animal, nor shall any person harm, maim or kill any
animal, or attempt to do so; except that a person may:
(1)
Defend such person's self or property or the person or property of another from injury or damage being caused
by an animal; or
(2)
Kill any animal causing injury or damage to livestock or poultry.
(c)
Physical abuse: It is unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously kill, maim, disfigure, torture, beat with a
stick, chain, club, or other object, mutilate, burn or scald with any substance, drive over or otherwise cruelly set
upon any animal, except that reasonable force may be employed to drive off vicious or trespassing animals.
(d)
Failure to care for and maintain: It is unlawful for any person to fail, refuse, or neglect to provide any animal in
such person's charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shade, care or shelter, or to carry
any animal in or upon any vehicle in a cruel or inhumane manner. Any animal habitually kept outside shall be
provided with a structurally sound, weatherproof enclosure, large enough to accommodate the animal.
(e)
Keeping diseased or crippled animal: It is unlawful for any person to have, keep, or harbor any animal which is
infected with any dangerous disease or any incurable, painfully crippling condition. The animal control
department may impound such diseased or painfully crippled animal, and all such animals impounded may be
disposed of humanely as soon thereafter as conveniently possible. In the case of humane disposition of such
animal, the animal control department shall not be required to give any notice. This section shall not be
construed to include veterinary hospitals or animals under active veterinary care.
(f)
Authority of animal control department in case of animal neglect: Whenever the animal control board finds that
any animal is or will be without proper care because of injury, illness, incarceration or other voluntary absence of
the owner or person responsible for the care of such animal, or because of the failure, refusal or neglect of the
owner or person responsible for the care of such animal to provide proper care, the animal control department
may pick up such animal for protective care; and in the event of sickness or injury, the animal control department
may take such action as called for to prevent undue pain and suffering, including immediate humane disposal of
the animal.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
78/414
(Ord. No. 88, § 29, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-5, 16-12-4.
Sec. 4-8. - Vicious animals.
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious
animal upon the public property, streets, alleys or rights-of-way of the city, or any other public place therein, or
on the premises of another, without permission, at any time, unless, in addition to the other requirements of this
chapter, such animal shall be securely muzzled and controlled by a leash or other physical attachment not longer
than six (6) feet to effectively prevent it from biting any person or other animal.
(Ord. No. 88, § 15, 9-11-89)
Cross reference— Dangerous dogs, § 4-40 et seq.
Sec. 4-9. - Application of provisions to exotic animals and other animals.
All sections of this chapter pertaining to vicious animals, dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs, shall
apply to all exotic animals, all animals other than those specifically mentioned herein, and any animal with a
known propensity to bite, and/or with a known vicious tendency.
(Ord. No. 88, § 19, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-10. - Biting animals—Impoundment.
Any animal which bites any person shall be impounded as provided for herein for a period of ten (10) days for
observation, and upon release to the owner shall be inoculated and tagged as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. No. 88, § 16, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Notice of bites, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4.
Sec. 4-11. - Same—Posting of premises.
The owner of any animal which bites any person as a first offender shall post on the premises where such first
offender is located a clearly visible sign warning "Beware of Dog," and/or "Beware of Animal."
(Ord. No. 88, § 17, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-12. - Rabies inoculation; tag and collar required; identification.
All dogs and cats located within the city shall be inoculated for rabies and shall wear a collar to which shall be
attached a valid vaccination tag and an identification tag, label or impression showing the name and address of
the owner of such dog or cat. In addition thereto, any other animal required by the laws of this state to be
inoculated or vaccinated shall have attached a valid vaccination tag.
(Ord. No. 88, § 9, 9-11-89)
Secs. 4-13—4-19. - Reserved.
ARTICLE II. - DOGS
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-20. - Dog control officer—Designated; arrest powers.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
79/414
With the consent of the county animal control, the director of the animal control and the director's designees shall
be designated as dog control officers as provided in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c) in cooperation with the city police
department in carrying out the duties of the dog control officer. A person shall not be authorized to make arrests
unless that person is a law enforcement officer having the powers of arrest.
(Ord. No. 88, § 20, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-21. - Same—Interference therewith.
No person shall hinder, molest, or interfere with any person authorized or empowered to perform any duty with
reference to dogs under this article.
(Ord. No. 88, § 13, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-22. - Dog census.
The chief of police shall annually cause a canvass to be made of all dogs owned or harbored within the city, and
shall report the results, including the names of all persons owning or harboring such animals, to the city clerk.
(Ord. No. 88, § 14, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-23. - Dogs at large—Generally.
Every dog within the city shall be either kept on a leash being held by the owner or kept within a fenced area or
other area which confines such dog to a limited area. Any dog found roaming the streets shall be forthwith seized
by the proper authority and the owner shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8.
(Ord. No. 88, § 33, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-24. - Same—Female dogs in heat.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any female dog to allow such dog to run at large while in heat.
(b)
Any person violating this section shall be caused to pay a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) after
trial and conviction in the municipal court.
(Ord. No. 88, § 32, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Permitting female dogs in heat to roam at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6.
Sec. 4-25. - Registration of attack and guard-security dog; fees.
(a)
The owner of an attack dog and/or a guard-security dog which is either housed, leased, rented, or utilized in the
city shall register such dog with the animal control officer as an attack and/or guard-security dog.
(b)
Upon registration the owner of an attack and/or guard-security dog shall pay, in addition to all other fees, a fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. No. 88, § 18, 9-11-89)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
80/414
Sec. 4-26. - Dog license—Required; application; evidence of inoculation required; issuance of tag.
(a)
Every person owning or harboring a dog within the city shall, on or before the fifteenth day of January in each
year, apply to the city clerk for a license for each dog so owned or harbored, and at the time of application shall
present and file with the city clerk a certificate signed by either: (1) a licensed veterinarian of the state showing
that such dog has been inoculated against rabies within one (1) year, or (2) by some properly qualified person
approved by the board of health. Whereupon, after the payment of the fee hereinafter set forth, the city clerk
shall issue to such person a license, together with an official tag, which tag shall be fastened to the collar of the
dog so licensed. In the event of a dog being acquired after the fifteenth day of January, a license shall be obtained
as aforesaid within one (1) month after the date of acquiring the animal.
(b)
No person shall attach a license tag to any dog to which it is not issued or remove a license tag from the collar of
any dog without the consent of its owner.
(Ord. No. 88, §§ 2, 13, 9-11-89)
Cross reference— Rabies inoculation, § 4-12.
Sec. 4-27. - Same—Fees; expiration; not applicable to "licensed kennels"; lost, etc., tags.
(a)
Initial: The fee for obtaining the dog license required shall be two dollars ($2.00) for each dog. Such license
shall expire on the thirty-first day of December of the year obtained. The license fee mentioned in this section
shall not apply to dogs in a licensed kennel.
(b)
Replacement of lost, etc., tags: If any such tag required is lost or destroyed, the owner, on making affidavit of
such loss before the city clerk and paying one dollar ($1.00), shall receive a new tag. The number of the lost tag
shall be noted on the city clerk's register and a list of such lost numbers shall be reported to and kept by the chief
of police.
(Ord. No. 88, §§ 6, 7, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-28. - Same—Delinquent applications.
For any application made thirty (30) days after the fifteenth day of January, the applicant shall be assessed a
penalty of fifty (50) percent of the license fee, which amount shall be added and collected with the regular
license fee. The aforesaid penalty is not applicable in the event the animal is acquired after the fifteenth day of
January. In this event, the above stated penalty will be enforced at the expiration of thirty (30) days after the date
of acquiring the animal.
(Ord. No. 88, § 3, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-29. - Kennel license.
The fee for obtaining a license known as a "kennel license" shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). Such license shall
only be issued to persons dealing in, boarding, or caring for dogs and shall cover all dogs in their custody,
provided, that each dog in the care and custody of any such person having a kennel license shall have been
vaccinated against rabies within one (1) year and shall bear an identification tag approved by the board of health,
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
81/414
showing that such dog has been properly inoculated against rabies. The word "kennel" shall apply to anyone
selling or boarding dogs.
(Ord. No. 88, § 8, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-30. - Transfer of licenses.
(a)
If there is a change in ownership of a dog or kennel during the license year, the new owner may have the current
license transferred to such person's name upon payment of a transfer fee of fifty cents ($0.50) to the city clerk.
(b)
Licenses are not transferable from one (1) animal to another.
(Ord. No. 88, §§ 4, 5, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-31. - Impoundment.
(a)
It shall be the duty of every police officer to seize and impound or cause to be seized and impounded, any dog at
large within the city not bearing tags as provided in this chapter.
(b)
Furthermore, all animals found at large upon public places or upon the premises of another or upon the public
streets, highways, alleys, and rights-of-way of the city, in violation of this chapter, shall be immediately
impounded by the animal control department. The city employees, or any other persons or delegated persons of
the animal control shall not be liable for any injury to any animal picked up under this section.
(Ord. No. 88, § 10, 9-11-89)
Cross reference— Redemption, § 4-3; disposition of unclaimed animal, § 4-4.
Sec. 4-32. - Barking, etc., dogs.
(a)
It shall be unlawful for any person to own or keep within the city any dog which, by barking, biting, howling, or
in any other manner, disturbs the quiet of any person.
(b)
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to cause, either by disturbance or by any other means, any dog
to bite, bark, howl, or in any other manner disturb the quiet of any person.
(c)
Any person violating the above provisions of this section shall be caused to pay a fine not to exceed one hundred
dollars ($100.00) after trial and conviction in the municipal court.
(Ord. No. 88, § 31, 9-11-89)
Secs. 4-33—4-39. - Reserved.
DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS OR POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOGS
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
82/414
Sec. 4-40. - Investigations; notice of classification as dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dogs.
(a)
Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within a dog control officer's
jurisdiction from any law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of
health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be
necessary to carry out the provisions of this division.
(b)
When a dog control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog or reclassifies a
potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner in writing, as
specified in section 4-41 herein, by certified mail to the owner's last known address of such classification. Such
notice shall be complete upon its mailing.
(Ord. No. 88, § 21, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23.
Sec. 4-41. - Procedure for classification as dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; notice, hearing.
(a)
As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedure provided for in this section must be
carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this division against such owners.
As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedure provided for in this section shall not be an essential
element of any crime provided for in this division.
(b)
When a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, the dog control officer shall notify the
dog's owner of such classification.
(c)
The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements:
(1)
The notice shall be in writing and mailing by certified mail to the owner's last-known address;
(2)
The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's
classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog.
(Ord. No. 88, § 22, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23.
Sec. 4-42. - Requirements for possessing dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs; registration, insurance, notice
to dog control officer, enforcement.
(a)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
83/414
It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess within this city a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog without a
certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25.
(b)
Subject to the additional requirements of subsection (c) of this section for dangerous dogs, the dog control officer
shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of such dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer, or
the dog control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of:
(1)
A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; and
(2)
The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly
visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property and containing a symbol designed to inform
children of the presence of a dangerous dog. Such sign shall be in the shape of a diamond, similar to a standard
highway warning sign, composed of eight-tenths (.08) gauge aluminum sheeting and measuring twelve (12) by
twelve (12) inches. The circle will measure ten and three-quarter (10¾) inches in diameter. The figure of the
person shall measure five (5) inches from the top of the figure's finger to the bottom of the figure's feet. The top
of the dog's tail to the person's elbow shall measure six and three-quarter (6¾) inches. The word "DANGER"
shall measure one and one-eighth (1⅛) inches by six (6) inches. The sign will utilize two (2) colors; standard
yellow and black. The background of the sign will be in standard yellow. The circle, the figures of the person and
dog, and the word "DANGER" will be in black. (See Figure 1)
Figure 1
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
84/414
(c)
The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within fifteen (15) days after the date shown on the
notice, has the right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous
dog or potentially dangerous dog:
(1)
The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board;
(2)
The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a
dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this division on a date
specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and
(3)
The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and shall provide specific
instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the agency.
(d)
When the animal control board receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it
shall schedule such hearing within thirty (30) days after receiving the request. The board shall notify the dog
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
85/414
owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time, and place of hearing, and such notice shall be mailed to the
dog owner at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be
given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and in addition thereto the board shall receive such other
evidence and hear such other testimony as the board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination
either to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog.
(e)
Within ten (10) days after the date of the hearing, the animal control board shall notify the dog owner in writing
by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a
potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective.
(f)
The owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer immediately
upon discovery if it is on the loose, unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If
the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address,
and telephone number of the new owner of the dog.
(g)
The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is
moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog
who is a new resident of the city shall register the dog as required in this section within thirty (30) days after
becoming a resident. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from another
jurisdiction to this city shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in this city within ten (10)
days after becoming a resident.
(h)
Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the city does not warrant
or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are maintained by the owner
of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the
initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate.
(i)
A dog control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the
provisions of this division. The chief of police shall cooperate with dog control officers in enforcing the
provisions of this division.
(j)
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25, the dog control officer shall charge an additional fee of one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) per year for registration of dangerous dogs and a registration fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
year for registration of potentially dangerous dogs. Such fees shall be in addition to all other fees normally
charged for the registration of dogs. Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time
of the annual renewal of a certificate of registration, a dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner
or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is
continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions
of this division.
(Ord. No. 88, § 23, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-43. - Restrictions on permitting dangerous or potentially dangerous dog to be outside of proper enclosure.
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
86/414
(a)
It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog
is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash not longer than six (6) feet and is under the physical
restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or
interfere with its vision or respiration, but will prevent it from biting any person.
(b)
It is unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure
unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash no longer than six (6) feet and is under the restraint of
a responsible person.
(Ord. No. 88, § 24, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-29.
Sec. 4-44. - Confiscation of dogs; grounds, disposition.
(a)
A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or
by another person authorized by the dog control officer if the:
(1)
Owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by O.C.G.A. § 2-4-23(c)(1), (2);
(2)
Dog is not validly registered as required by section 4-42(a);
(3)
Dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or
(4)
Dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 4-42(b)(1).
(b)
A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is:
(1)
Not validly registered as required by section 4-42(a);
(2)
Not maintained in a proper enclosure; or
(3)
Outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 4-42(b)(1).
(c)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
87/414
Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be returned to
its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this division and upon the payment of reasonable
confiscation costs. The city or the animal control board shall not be liable for any injury to any animal picked up
in violation of this division. In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within
twenty (20) days after the dog was confiscated, such dog shall be disposed of in an expeditious and recognized
humane manner by the animal control department.
(d)
The owner of the dog shall pay the city the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a confiscation fee, whether
the owner shall claim the dog or not.
(Ord. No. 88, § 25, 9-11-89)
State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-30.
Sec. 4-45. - Violation; penalties.
(a)
The owner of a dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 4-41 or section 4-42 or whose
dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under subsection (a) of section 4-44 shall be incarcerated for a period of
up to sixty (60) days. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this
subsection, a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be imposed for the first conviction, a fine of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for the second conviction, and the owner shall be punished under the
provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(b) for the third conviction.
(b)
The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 4-41 or section 4-42
or whose potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under subsection (b) of section 4-44 shall be
incarcerated for a period of up to sixty (60) days. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a
conviction under this subsection, a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be imposed for the first
conviction, a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be imposed for the second conviction, and a fine of
three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be imposed for the third conviction.
(c)
If an owner who has a previous conviction for a violation of this division knowingly and wilfully fails to comply
with the provisions of this division, charges against such owner shall be referred to the district attorney for
prosecution under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(c) or (d) if the owner's dangerous dog attacks or bites a
human being under circumstances constituting another violation of this division.
(d)
In addition to the penalties for violation under subsection (c) of this section, the dangerous dog involved shall be
immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by law enforcement officers or another person authorized
by the dog control officer and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county
board of health, thereafter, the dangerous dog shall be disposed of in an expeditious and recognized humane
manner by the animal control department.
(Ord. No. 88, § 26, 9-11-89)
Sec. 4-46. - Exceptions.
(a)
5/10/2019 Grovetown, GA Code of Ordinances
88/414
A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out
the law enforcement officer's official duties or is a guard-security dog or attack dog which is being used for guard
and/or security purposes shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this
division.
(b)
A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this division if the
injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a wilful trespass or other
tort or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have
tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime.
(c)
No owner of a dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this division for injuries inflicted by such
owner's dog to any human being while on such owner's property and within the enclosure as described in section
4-1, if such injured person was a trespasser upon the land.
(Ord. No. 88, § 27, 9-11-89)
Cross reference— Impoundment of biting animal, § 4-10.

Sec. 5-2. - Building contractors—Performance bond and insurance coverage required.
(a)
Every contractor, builder, electrician, plumber or mechanical contractor who shall make contracts for the
erection, construction or repair of buildings, or any portion thereof, for which a permit is required, and every
contractor or builder making such contracts and subletting such contracts, or any part thereof, [are required] to
do the following:
(1)
Execute and deposit with the planning and zoning department a bond in the sum of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) for each commercial unit under construction and fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for each
residential unit under construction, to be conditioned that all work performed by the contractor or under his
supervision shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and other pertinent laws and
ordinances. The contractor will pay all fees and penalties properly imposed upon him for violations of the
provisions of this section.
(2)
Place on file in the planning and zoning department a certificate of insurance for public liability and property
damage for an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person, and two
hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for each occurrence.
(3)
Place on file in the planning and zoning department a certificate of insurance for worker's compensation
insurance for an amount not less than two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for each person employed.
(4)
Shall obtain proper licensing through the Georgia Secretary of State beginning January 1, 2008.
(b)
The maximum penalty for any violation of this section shall be a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00), six (6) months in jail and twelve (12) months of probation. Each occurrence shall be deemed a
separate violation.
(Ord. No. 174, §§ 1, 2, 10-10-06)
Sec. 5-3. - Construction sites to be kept clean.
(a)
All construction sites located in the city limits of the City of Grovetown shall be kept clean of any and all
construction related debris such as paint buckets, remnant lumber, product packaging, etc. It will be the
responsibility of the builder or owner of the site to make sure the construction site is checked on a weekly basis
and any items that need to be removed from the construction site will be properly disposed of in a municipal
solid waste landfill.

(b)
Port-o-let facilities must be maintained and pumped on a regular basis and must not contain any leaks. Any
repairs that are needed must be done in a timely manner. Once the port-o-let has been vacuumed, the port-o-let
contractor must dispose of the waste into a permitted disposal facility or municipal sewer.
(c)
Failure to keep the construction site free of construction related debris or failure to perform regular maintenance
of port-o-let facilities will be subject to enforcement and penalties as defined in sections 5-26 and 5-27 of the
City of Grovetown Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance.
